New Records: The Padres hit a postseason-record tying six home runs in Game 3 of the NLDS against the Dodgers.
Key Match Events: The Padres defeated the Dodgers, 10-2, in Game 3 of the NLDS.
Fans directed profanities and obscene gestures to Padres outfielder Fernando Tatis Jr. after he blew kisses to the stands and seemed to strut after making a catch in the fourth inning.
Dodger pitcher Jack Flaherty verbally sparred with Padres' third baseman Manny Machado in the sixth inning.
Fans threw two baseballs into the outfield and beer cans and water bottles onto the field before the start of the seventh inning, prompting an approximately 10-minute delay.
Pre-Game Insights: Petco Park officials reminded fans of its code of conduct ahead of Game 3, emphasizing a zero-tolerance policy for violations.
Dodgers manager Dave Roberts commented on the expected hostile and noisy environment for Game 3.
Padres ace right-hander Michael King is set to take the mound for Game 3.
King mentioned he would take confidence from his previous performance but acknowledged the need for a different approach against the Dodgers.
King's last appearance against the Dodgers resulted in a win, allowing one run and three hits in five innings.
Dodger designated hitter Shohei Ohtani has a strong batting record against King, with a .429 lifetime average and three home runs.
Dodgers' Walker Buehler will make his eighth start since returning from a rehabilitation assignment, with a 0-2 record and a 5.20 ERA since his return.
Buehler has a lifetime 6-1 record with a 1.82 ERA against the Padres.
Post-Match Reflections: Dodgers manager Dave Roberts found it bothersome and unsettling that a ball thrown by Manny Machado seemed intended for him.
Padres manager Mike Shildt praised Michael King's competitive spirit and pitching skills.
Miscellaneous Highlights: ESPN's matchup predictor gives the Padres a 64.7% chance of winning Game 3, while the Dodgers have a 35.3% chance.
